items.title: Paint Peeling on Wood: 180 Grit Wood Paint Prep
items.description: Paint Peeling on Wood? Use 180 grit for wood paint prep. Fix common wood prep issues before paint or primer so the finish lays down smooth. Sand with the grain, check your scratch pattern in good light, and clean dust before coating. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Bumps After First Coat: 220 Grit Sanding Between Coats
items.description: Bumps After First Coat? Use 220 grit for sanding between coats. Lightly scuff sand between coats to knock down nibs and keep the next coat smooth. Use light pressure, keep the surface flat, and stop as soon as it feels even. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Old Paint Still On the Wood: 80 Grit Removing Old Paint
items.description: Old Paint Still On the Wood? Use 80 grit for removing old paint. Remove loose paint or old finish in controlled passes to avoid gouging the wood. Start with the recommended grit, vacuum dust, then step up in grit before repainting. Wet or dry use. — eQualle

items.title: Stain Looks Blotchy: 180 Grit Wood Stain Prep
items.description: Stain Looks Blotchy? Use 180 grit for wood stain prep. Prep wood for stain by evening scratch patterns so color absorbs more consistently. Sand with the grain, wipe off dust, and test your stain on a small area first. Wet or dry use. — eQualle
